selected_quotes: Current Issue: Nielsen et al: the diversity of Penicilllium secondary metabolite potential #antibiotics clusters: ht…
Nielsen co: the diversity of Penicilllium secondary metabolite potential #antibiotics synthesis clusters
Highlight of the study by Jens Nielsen and col on secondary metabolite potential of Penicillium spp
Global analysis of biosynthetic gene clusters reveals vast potential of SM production in Penicillium species
Fungi present a potential gold mine for antibiotic development--especially critical in the face of growing antibio…

citation.abstract: Filamentous fungi produce a wide range of bioactive compounds with important pharmaceutical applications, such as antibiotic penicillins and cholesterol-lowering statins. However, less attention has been paid to fungal secondary metabolites compared to those from bacteria. In this study, we sequenced the genomes of 9 Penicillium species and, together with 15 published genomes, we investigated the secondary metabolism of Penicillium and identified an immense, unexploited potential for producing secondary metabolites by this genus. A total of 1,317 putative biosynthetic gene clusters (BGCs) were identified, and polyketide synthase and non-ribosomal peptide synthetase based BGCs were grouped into gene cluster families and mapped to known pathways. The grouping of BGCs allowed us to study the evolutionary trajectory of pathways based on 6-methylsalicylic acid (6-MSA) synthases. Finally, we cross-referenced the predicted pathways with published data on the production of secondary metabolites and experimentally validated the production of antibiotic yanuthones in Penicillia and identified a previously undescribed compound from the yanuthone pathway. This study is the first genus-wide analysis of the genomic diversity of Penicillia and highlights the potential of these species as a source of new antibiotics and other pharmaceuticals.
authors: Jens Christian  Froslev Nielsen, Sietske Grijseels, Sylvain Prigent, Boyang Ji, Jacques Dainat, Kristian Fog Nielsen, Jens Christian Frisvad, Mhairi Workman, Jens B. Nielsen
citation.title: Global analysis of biosynthetic gene clusters reveals vast potential of secondary metabolite production in Penicillium species

“Big Potential of New Secondary Metabolite Production in Fungi”

Penicillia are commonly found in temperate and tropical climates growing on organic matter, such as soil, plant residues, dung and food materials. In a study published in Nature Microbiology,

facebook.title: Global analysis of biosynthetic gene clusters reveals vast potential of secondary metabolite production in Penicillium species
facebook.summary:
越來越多的細菌開始對抗生素產生抗藥性，為未來的醫療帶來隱憂，尋找新型抗生素成為迫切的研究主題。瑞典Chalmers University of Technology 團隊從真菌著手，希望能從真菌的基因體中，發現更多的可能性。研究團隊先將9種Penicillium進行基因體定序，再與其他15種已被公開的真菌基因體序列進行比對分析，發現了超過1000個生合成路徑，主要是Polyketide及NRPS生理活性物質，之基因叢集(genes clusters)，其中有許多路徑可能產生新型的化合物。
